review: As long as you understand what this is, it works perfectly.  It is not a stand alone device.  It needs a computer with a Chrome browser or a smartphone, tablet, iPad or PC with a compatible app, that once started on the smartphone, tablet or whatever, is then "passed to" (or "cast") to the Chromecast where the Chromecast then displays the app on your TV.  For example.  Netflix.  I start Netflix on my phone.  On the Netflix screen is a "cast to Chromecast" icon.  I select that icon, it asks which Chromecast to send Netflix to and gives a list of Chromecast devices it find on YOUR home network.  You select the Chromecast and a tiny stub program is sent to the Chromecase that then connects the Chromecast to Netflix and plays whatever it was you selected from your smartphone.  Pause, fast forward and so forth are still done via your smartphone.  There is no separate "remote".  The video is not displayed on your smartphone.  In fact, you can actually turn your smartphone (or PC or whatever) OFF and the video will continue to play as it is streamed directly to your Chromecast from Netflix, not to you phone, and then to the Chromecast.  BUT, realize that if you do that (turn your smartphone off), you will no longer be able to control pause, play, start, fast forward or fast reverse.  It's a great device, I love mine!
